Title: CourseAssist: Pedagogically Appropriate AI Tutor for Computer Science Education
Description: The paper introduces CourseAssist, an AI-based tutoring system designed specifically for computer science education, which leverages retrieval-augmented generation, user intent classification, and question decomposition to provide pedagogically appropriate responses aligned with course materials. The system was evaluated against GPT-4, showing improved usefulness, accuracy, and pedagogical appropriateness, and has been deployed in multiple courses, enhancing the accessibility and effectiveness of tutoring for over 500 students.

Title: Ethics, Governance, and User Mental Models for Large Language Models in Computing Education
Description: The paper explores the ethical considerations, governance frameworks, and user mental models associated with the integration of large language models in computing education, aiming to inform policy development to enhance learning outcomes.

Title: Generative AI in Computer Science Education
Description: The paper explores the integration of generative AI tools in computer science education, focusing on lesson design, code development, test design, and assessment. It addresses both student and educator perspectives, aiming to equip participants with the skills to effectively incorporate generative AI into educational practices, thereby enhancing teaching methodologies and learning experiences.

Title: AI in Computing Education from Research to Practice
Description: The paper discusses a panel of computing educators exploring the integration of AI into computing education, focusing on AI applications in introductory courses, opportunities with large language models (LLMs), development of LLM-based tools, and the incorporation of ethics and inclusion in AI curricula, thereby highlighting experiences, opportunities, and challenges in AI education.

Title: Discussing the Changing Landscape of Generative AI in Computing Education
Description: The paper explores the evolving role of generative AI in computing education, addressing challenges such as academic integrity, curriculum changes, and pedagogical strategies. It aims to foster collaborative discussions among educators and researchers to develop strategies for integrating AI responsibly into educational practices.

Title: Generative AI in CS Education: Literature Review through a SWOT Lens
Description: The paper conducts a SWOT analysis of existing literature on the use of generative AI in computer science education, identifying strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats. It provides use cases and guidelines to help integrate AI tools like ChatGPT into educational settings, highlighting both potential benefits and challenges.

Title: “It's not like Jarvis, but it's pretty close!” - Examining ChatGPT's Usage among Undergraduate Students in Computer Science
Description: This paper investigates the usage of ChatGPT by undergraduate computer science students, employing surveys and interviews to understand its benefits, challenges, and potential improvements. The study reveals a generally positive student perception of ChatGPT as a coursework aid, while also identifying challenges that need addressing for its sustained acceptance in educational contexts.

Title: The Robots Are Here: Navigating the Generative AI Revolution in Computing Education
Description: This paper explores the impact of generative AI, particularly large language models, on computing education by reviewing literature, surveying global attitudes, interviewing educators, discussing ethical considerations, and benchmarking AI tools. It aims to guide educators and policymakers in adapting pedagogy to leverage AI advancements for more effective and inclusive learning experiences.

Title: Evaluating ChatGPT-4 Vision on Brazil's National Undergraduate Computer Science Exam
Description: The paper evaluates the performance of ChatGPT-4 Vision, a multimodal large language model, on Brazil's 2021 National Undergraduate Computer Science Exam, demonstrating its ability to outperform average human participants and highlighting its potential as a tool for question testing and refinement. The study also identifies challenges in question interpretation and logical reasoning, emphasizing the need for human oversight and improved question design in educational assessments.

Title: Early Adoption of Generative Artificial Intelligence in Computing Education: Emergent Student Use Cases and Perspectives in 2023
Description: The paper explores the early adoption and perceptions of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) among computer science students at a small engineering-focused university. It provides a qualitative analysis of student attitudes, usage patterns, and concerns, offering insights into the implications of GenAI on computing education, pedagogy, and policy development.

Title: Prompt Engineering for Large Language Models to Support K-8 Computer Science Teachers in Creating Culturally Responsive Projects
Description: The paper explores the use of large language models to assist K-8 computer science teachers in creating culturally responsive programming projects. It contributes by developing a framework for assessing AI-generated project ideas and providing insights into teachers' perspectives on integrating these models into educational practices.

Title: Differentiated Tasks by ChatGPT for Secondary Computer Science Education: Useful or not?
Description: The paper explores the use of ChatGPT-4 to create differentiated tasks for secondary computer science education, developing a tool that utilizes didactical parameters to tailor these tasks. Preliminary findings suggest that teachers find the tool beneficial, indicating potential for enhancing K-12 education with AI-driven task differentiation.

Title: AI Education in German K-10 Computer Science Curricula
Description: This paper analyzes the inclusion of artificial intelligence (AI) content in K-10 computer science curricula across Germany's 16 federal states, revealing inconsistencies and a lack of standardized AI competencies. It advocates for the integration of mandatory AI education that encompasses technological, socio-cultural, and user-oriented perspectives to ensure comprehensive and up-to-date learning.

Title: Beyond Code Generation: An Observational Study of ChatGPT Usage in Software Engineering Practice
Description: The paper conducts an observational study of 24 professional software engineers using ChatGPT in their work, revealing that engineers primarily use the tool for guidance and learning rather than direct code generation. It introduces a theoretical framework that considers interaction purpose, user personality, and external factors to understand the perceived usefulness and trust in LLMs, aiming to guide future research and design in this area.

Title: Computing Education in the Era of Generative AI
Description: The paper explores the challenges and opportunities that arise in computing education due to the advent of large language models (LLMs) capable of generating accurate source code from natural-language problem descriptions, highlighting the need for educators and students to adapt to these technological advancements.

Title: No More Pencils No More Books: Capabilities of Generative AI on Irish and UK Computer Science School Leaving Examinations
Description: The paper evaluates the performance of ChatGPT (GPT-4) on UK A-Level and Irish Leaving Certificate computer science exams, highlighting its ability to achieve high marks and identifying areas where it struggles, such as questions involving symbols or images. The study provides insights into the strengths and weaknesses of these exams in the context of generative AI, with implications for exam design and marking schemes.

Title: ChatGPT in Computer Science Curriculum Assessment: An analysis of Its Successes and Shortcomings
Description: The paper evaluates the use of ChatGPT as a tool for learning and assessment in undergraduate Computer Science courses, specifically focusing on programming challenges in a Data Structures and Algorithms course. It finds that while ChatGPT can enhance student performance, it also introduces inconsistencies and inaccuracies, highlighting both the potential benefits and challenges of integrating AI tools into higher education curricula.

Title: Transformed by Transformers: Navigating the AI Coding Revolution for Computing Education: An ITiCSE Working Group Conducted by Humans
Description: The paper documents the current state-of-the-art in code generation using large language models (LLMs) and explores their potential applications and challenges in computing education. It provides actionable strategies for integrating these technologies into educational curricula to enhance learning and teaching processes.

Title: Bob or Bot: Exploring ChatGPT's Answers to University Computer Science Assessment
Description: The paper investigates the impact of ChatGPT on university computer science assessments by evaluating its ability to generate passing answers for undergraduate modules, while failing postgraduate ones. It highlights the implications of generative AI on academic integrity and quality assurance, providing insights into detection methods and the potential for AI-generated content to affect educational assessments.

Title: Understanding Algorithmic Problem Solving using LLMs
Description: The paper investigates the capability of Large Language Models (LLMs), specifically GPT-4o, in assisting students with algorithmic problem solving by using prompt refinement techniques. It demonstrates that LLMs can effectively translate problem statements into natural language descriptions, code solutions, correctness arguments, and runtime analyses, particularly excelling with problems similar to those encountered during training.

Title: Using Benchmarking Infrastructure to Evaluate LLM Performance on CS Concept Inventories: Challenges, Opportunities, and Critiques
Description: The paper investigates the use of automated benchmarking frameworks to evaluate the performance of large language models (LLMs) on computer science concept inventories, highlighting the challenges and opportunities in this approach. It provides insights into LLM capabilities in computing education tasks, identifies areas where LLMs struggle, and discusses methodological challenges, ultimately aiming to enhance the design of computing assessments in light of LLM advancements.

Title: Experiences with Remote Examination Formats in Light of GPT-4
Description: The paper investigates the impact of GPT-4 on remote examination formats in a Software Engineering BSc program, comparing oral and open-book exams. It finds that while GPT-4 can compromise open-book exams, grade distributions remain stable across formats, suggesting oral exams as a viable alternative despite increased teacher workload and stress.

Title: Evaluating ChatGPT and GPT-4 for Visual Programming
Description: The paper evaluates the performance of ChatGPT and GPT-4 in visual programming environments used in K-8 education, such as Scratch and Code.org's Maze Challenge. It finds that these models struggle with tasks requiring spatial, logical, and programming skills, highlighting the need for new benchmarks to assess and improve future AI models in visual programming contexts.

Title: Automatically Generating CS Learning Materials with Large Language Models
Description: The paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) to automatically generate computer science learning materials, such as code explanations and programming assignments, highlighting their potential to enhance student interaction with code and assist instructors in scaling educational resources. It also addresses the implications of LLMs on academic integrity, curriculum design, and software engineering careers, and engages educators in evaluating and brainstorming their integration into pedagogy and research.

Title: Automating Human Tutor-Style Programming Feedback: Leveraging GPT-4 Tutor Model for Hint Generation and GPT-3.5 Student Model for Hint Validation
Description: The paper introduces a novel technique, GPT4HINTS-GPT3.5VAL, which utilizes GPT-4 to generate human tutor-style programming hints and GPT-3.5 to validate these hints for quality. This approach aims to enhance the quality of automated feedback in programming education, demonstrating its effectiveness through evaluations on datasets of Python programs.

Title: Thrilled by Your Progress! Large Language Models (GPT-4) No Longer Struggle to Pass Assessments in Higher Education Programming Courses
Description: The paper evaluates the performance of GPT-4 in passing assessments from introductory and intermediate Python programming courses, demonstrating significant improvements over previous GPT models. It highlights GPT-4's ability to pass these courses autonomously, suggesting a need for educators to reconsider assessment designs and teaching methods in light of advanced AI capabilities.

Title: An Investigation of the Drivers of Novice Programmers' Intentions to Use Web Search and GenAI
Description: The paper investigates the factors influencing novice programmers' intentions to use web search and Generative AI (GenAI) tools in educational settings, contrasting perceptions between freshmen and seniors. It identifies key behavioral factors, such as perceived benefits and justifiability, that affect tool usage intentions and provides insights for educators on how to guide resource usage in classrooms.

Title: Using Large Language Models for Teaching Computing
Description: The paper explores the integration of large language models (LLMs) into computing education, proposing their use as tools to enhance learning by allowing students to interact with LLMs and understand their limitations, thereby equipping educators with strategies to effectively incorporate LLMs into their teaching practices.

Title: Generating Diverse Code Explanations using the GPT-3 Large Language Model
Description: The paper explores the use of the GPT-3 large language model to automatically generate diverse natural language explanations for code snippets, aiming to enhance learning by providing multiple perspectives on code understanding. The main contribution is a systematic analysis of GPT-3's ability to produce varied explanations, highlighting three specific use cases within an evolving design space for AI-generated code explanations.

Title: Assessing AI Detectors in Identifying AI-Generated Code: Implications for Education
Description: The paper conducts an empirical study to evaluate the effectiveness of AI-generated content detectors in distinguishing between human-written and AI-generated code, using a dataset of Python solutions from various sources. The study reveals that current detectors struggle to accurately identify AI-generated code, highlighting potential challenges for educators in preventing academic misconduct.

Title: Using Large Language Models To Diagnose Math Problem-solving Skills At Scale
Description: The paper introduces a large language model (LLM) pipeline designed to diagnose elementary school students' math problem-solving skills at scale by analyzing their answers through a framework called PERC, which breaks down problem-solving into four stages. The main contribution is the development and evaluation of this pipeline, which uses rubrics to assess each stage of problem-solving, demonstrating improved diagnostic accuracy over standard LLMs like GPT-3.5 and GPT-4.

Title: Examining the Relationship between Socioeconomic Status and Beliefs about Large Language Models in an Undergraduate Programming Course
Description: The paper investigates the relationship between socioeconomic status and students' perceptions and usage of large language models (LLMs) in an undergraduate programming course. It finds that higher socioeconomic status correlates with a belief in LLMs' potential for career success, while lower-SES students view LLMs as useful for learning but not crucial for long-term career success, highlighting the influence of social and cultural factors on technology perception.

Title: The Implications of Large Language Models for CS Teachers and Students
Description: The paper discusses the implications of Large Language Models (LLMs) in computer science education, focusing on their potential benefits and drawbacks for both students and teachers. It aims to raise awareness and foster a community around the use of LLMs in educational settings, facilitating discussions on their role and impact in enhancing learning experiences.

Title: Generative AI in Software Development Education: Insights from a Degree Apprenticeship Programme
Description: The paper explores the integration of ChatGPT into assignments within a Software Engineering Degree Apprenticeship program, providing insights into the perceptions of both learners and employers regarding the use of generative AI in educational settings.

Title: Using an LLM to Help With Code Understanding
Description: The paper investigates the use of a large language model (LLM) integrated into an IDE to assist with code understanding by providing explanations, API details, and usage examples without requiring explicit prompts. Through a user study, the authors demonstrate that this LLM-based tool enhances task completion compared to traditional web search, highlighting its potential as a valuable resource for both students and professional developers.

Title: Guidelines for the Evolving Role of Generative AI in Introductory Programming Based on Emerging Practice
Description: The paper examines the integration of Generative AI in introductory programming courses by analyzing early adopter practices and synthesizing insights from recent studies. It proposes flexible guidelines for instructors to adapt their teaching methods, highlighting key considerations for incorporating GenAI into CS1 courses.

Title: Students' Perceptions and Use of Generative AI Tools for Programming Across Different Computing Courses
Description: This paper investigates how students in various computing courses perceive and utilize generative AI tools for programming tasks, analyzing responses from surveys conducted over three academic terms. The study contributes to understanding how GenAI tool usage varies across different educational contexts and evolves over time, offering insights into aligning GenAI use with course learning objectives.

Title: Teaching IT Software Fundamentals: Strategies and Techniques for Inclusion of Large Language Models: Strategies and Techniques for Inclusion of Large Language Models
Description: The paper discusses the integration of AI Large Language Models (LLMs) into IT undergraduate courses focused on software fundamentals, proposing strategies to incorporate these tools in a way that enhances learning without compromising students' understanding of core software concepts. It highlights the importance of familiarizing students with LLMs like OpenAI Codex and GitHub Copilot, which are prevalent in the industry, while ensuring they still learn essential skills such as coding and debugging.

Title: The Case for LLM Workshops
Description: The paper presents a case study on developing workshops for faculty at small liberal arts universities to educate them on the responsible use of Large Language Models (LLMs) in teaching. It contributes an intellectual framework and practical strategies for integrating LLMs into curricula, addressing ethical considerations, and modifying assignments to incorporate and withstand LLM usage.

Title: Teaching Programming in the Age of Generative AI
Description: The paper explores the impact of generative AI on programming education, questioning the traditional role of programming in computer science curricula and proposing a reevaluation of its place in education. It argues for a nuanced approach to teaching programming, considering it both as part of a comprehensive curriculum and as a vocational skill, using philosophical and literary frameworks to interpret these changes.

Title: Attitudes Towards the Use (and Misuse) of ChatGPT: A Preliminary Study
Description: This paper conducted an online survey to assess computer science students' awareness, experience, and attitudes towards ChatGPT, finding that while it is primarily used as a study tool, there is a minority who misuse it, highlighting the need for educators to adapt teaching strategies and guidelines for its use in academic settings.

Title: Debugging with Open-Source Large Language Models: An Evaluation
Description: This paper evaluates the performance of open-source large language models in debugging tasks by testing five models on the DebugBench benchmark, which includes over 4000 buggy code instances in Python, Java, and C++. The study finds that open-source LLMs can achieve debugging success rates between 43.9% and 66.6%, with DeepSeek-Coder performing best across all tested programming languages.

Title: Instructor Perceptions of AI Code Generation Tools - A Multi-Institutional Interview Study
Description: The paper conducted a multi-institutional interview study with 12 instructors from Australia, Finland, and New Zealand to explore their perceptions, practices, concerns, and planned adaptations regarding AI code generation tools in computing education, aiming to inform new pedagogical strategies and foster dialogue between researchers and educators.

Title: Integrating Natural Language Processing in Middle School Science Classrooms: An Experience Report
Description: The paper reports on the integration of natural language processing (NLP) into middle school science classrooms, involving 98 students across two US states. It details the development of an NLP-based interactive visualization platform and learning activities, aiming to enhance student engagement and understanding of NLP, and provides practical insights and guidelines for educators and curriculum designers in K-12 education.

Title: A Self-Regulated Learning Framework using Generative AI and its Application in CS Educational Intervention Design
Description: The paper proposes a self-regulated learning framework that integrates generative AI tools to enhance programming problem-solving skills in novices, addressing both the challenges and opportunities these technologies present for self-regulation strategies in computer science education. The main contribution is the exploration and design of educational interventions that leverage generative AI to promote effective self-regulated learning strategies.

Title: Evaluating the Performance of Code Generation Models for Solving Parsons Problems With Small Prompt Variations
Description: The paper evaluates the performance of the OpenAI Codex model in solving Parsons problems, which involve reordering scrambled lines of code, to assess its applicability in computing education. It finds that Codex successfully reorders the code blocks about half the time, highlighting the model's limitations in structured problem-solving tasks and the impact of prompt variations on its performance.

Title: Significant Trends in CS Educational Material: Current and Future
Description: The paper explores current and future trends in computer science educational materials, emphasizing the integration of AI tools like OpenAI CodeX and GPT-3 in teaching programming. It highlights the shift from traditional textbooks to interactive online learning systems and discusses the challenges and opportunities for interoperability with educational platforms, contributing to the development of the "Future of CS educational materials" document for the CS2023 curriculum.

Title: TreeQuestion: Assessing Conceptual Learning Outcomes with LLM-Generated Multiple-Choice Questions
Description: The paper introduces TreeQuestion, a human-in-the-loop system that leverages large language models to generate multiple-choice questions for assessing students' conceptual learning outcomes, aiming to reduce the time teachers spend on creating and grading assessments. The study found that TreeQuestion-generated questions resulted in similar student performance compared to traditional open-ended questions, while significantly decreasing the teachers' workload.

Title: The Effects of Generative AI on Computing Students’ Help-Seeking Preferences
Description: This paper investigates the impact of generative AI tools on the help-seeking behaviors of computing students, revealing that while these tools are increasingly adopted, they have not replaced traditional resources. The study highlights the need for developing skills to effectively use AI for help-seeking and discusses implications for integrating AI into educational settings.

Title: Using Large Language Models to Enhance Programming Error Messages
Description: The paper explores the use of large language models to enhance programming error messages by providing explanations and suggestions, making them more understandable and actionable for novice programmers. This approach demonstrates the potential of language models to improve educational tools in computing, offering insights into their benefits and limitations.

Title: Unveiling the Potential of a Conversational Agent in Developer Support: Insights from Mozilla’s PDF.js Project
Description: The paper introduces DevMentorAI, a conversational agent designed to assist developers in Open Source Software projects by leveraging foundation models and the Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) architecture to provide relevant answers to developer queries. Through a case study on Mozilla's PDF.js project, the tool demonstrated its potential to enhance developer support by delivering satisfactory responses, thereby reducing the workload on core developers.

Title: Data-driven Contribution-based Disciplinary Assessment System
Description: The paper introduces a data-driven, contribution-based disciplinary assessment system for Computer Science Education that evaluates both theoretical and practical contributions. By integrating intelligent algorithms and a Large Language Model, the system automates data collection and analysis, reducing the workload on educators and aligning discipline development with societal needs.

Title: Roles of ChatGPT in virtual teaching assistant and intelligent tutoring system: opportunities and challenges
Description: The paper explores the potential roles and challenges of using ChatGPT, specifically GPT-4, as a Virtual Teaching Assistant and Intelligent Tutoring System in education. It conducts a comprehensive literature review to assess the benefits and challenges, such as response reliability and data privacy, providing insights for educators, policymakers, and developers to effectively integrate AI into educational settings.

Title: Generative Students: Using LLM-Simulated Student Profiles to Support Question Item Evaluation
Description: The paper introduces "Generative Students," a method using large language models (LLMs) to simulate student profiles for evaluating multiple-choice questions (MCQs). By generating responses based on simulated knowledge components, the approach aligns well with real student responses, aiding instructors in improving question quality through insights from these generative profiles.

Title: Automated Generation and Tagging of Knowledge Components from Multiple-Choice Questions
Description: The paper explores the use of GPT-4 to automate the generation and tagging of Knowledge Components (KCs) for multiple-choice questions in Chemistry and E-Learning, comparing the effectiveness of AI-generated KCs with those created by humans. It demonstrates that AI-generated KCs are often preferred by experts and introduces an ontology induction algorithm to cluster questions by similar KCs, enhancing the automation of assessment item classification without requiring predefined labels.

Title: Probeable Problems for Beginner-level Programming-with-AI Contests
Description: The paper introduces "Probeable Problems," a novel type of beginner-level programming contest problem designed to remain challenging even with the use of AI code-generation tools by omitting certain details and allowing participants to probe for these details through clarifying questions. The main contribution is the demonstration of this approach's effectiveness in maintaining problem-solving engagement in a programming contest setting, as evidenced by a study involving undergraduate students.

Title: Use of AI-driven Code Generation Models in Teaching and Learning Programming: a Systematic Literature Review
Description: This paper conducts a systematic literature review of 21 studies to evaluate the use of LLM-based code generation models in programming education, highlighting their roles in generating assignments, evaluating student work, and acting as virtual tutors. It identifies both the potential benefits and risks, such as accuracy limitations and academic misconduct, emphasizing the need for careful integration into educational practices.

Title: ChatGPT in IT Education Ecosystem: Unraveling Long-Term Impacts on Job Market, Student Learning, and Ethical Practices
Description: The paper investigates the long-term impacts of integrating ChatGPT into IT education, focusing on its effects on job market dynamics, student learning attitudes, and ethical practices. It provides insights into how ChatGPT may influence job automation, student skill development, and proposes methods to promote ethical use of AI in educational settings.

Title: Developing Computing Teacher Guidance on GenAI
Description: The paper established a working group of computing teachers to develop a guidance booklet on the use of Generative AI in educational settings, highlighting the effectiveness of teacher-researcher collaborations in creating practical resources for schools.

Title: Exploring the Role of ChatGPT in Education: Applications and Challenges
Description: The paper investigates the applications and challenges of using ChatGPT in the education sector, highlighting its potential to enhance personalized learning and streamline educational tasks, while also addressing concerns such as academic dishonesty and the difficulty in detecting AI-generated content.

Title: ChatGPT on ChatGPT: An Exploratory Analysis of its Performance in the Public Sector Workplace
Description: The paper conducts an exploratory analysis of ChatGPT's impact on the public sector workforce in the United States, assessing its potential for task automation and augmentation across various occupations. It identifies tasks susceptible to automation, highlights essential skills for the future, and proposes a framework for adapting workforce development and educational curricula to integrate AI technologies effectively.

Title: Learning Agent-based Modeling with LLM Companions: Experiences of Novices and Experts Using ChatGPT & NetLogo Chat
Description: The paper investigates the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT to assist in learning and practicing agent-based modeling (ABM) with NetLogo, highlighting differences in perceptions and needs between novice and expert users. It identifies key areas such as guidance, personalization, and integration as essential for enhancing LLM-based interfaces to better support ABM programming.

Title: Designing and Generating Lesson Plans combining Open Educational Content and Generative AI
Description: The paper presents a method for creating lesson plans for complex subjects like Model-Driven Engineering by integrating Open Educational Resources with generative AI techniques. It introduces a metamodel to guide educators in defining learning objectives and activities, supported by tools that facilitate the development of teaching materials, demonstrating the approach's potential in enhancing educational content design.

Title: Understanding the Role of Large Language Models in Personalizing and Scaffolding Strategies to Combat Academic Procrastination
Description: The paper explores the potential of large language models (LLMs) to personalize interventions for academic procrastination by conducting interviews and focus groups with students and experts. It identifies the need for LLMs to offer structured, deadline-oriented advice and adaptive questioning, providing design implications for developing LLM-based tools to manage procrastination effectively.

Title: Exploring Human-Centered Approaches in Generative AI and Introductory Programming Research: A Scoping Review
Description: This paper conducts a scoping review of 28 studies to assess the integration of generative artificial intelligence in introductory programming education, highlighting benefits, concerns, and gaps such as insufficient pedagogical guidance and limited student perspective consideration. It emphasizes the need for more human-centered research approaches and provides recommendations for future studies to enhance the understanding of AI's role in programming education.

Title: DSL-Xpert: LLM-driven Generic DSL Code Generation
Description: The paper introduces DSL-Xpert, a tool that leverages large language models (LLMs) to perform semantic parsing, translating natural language instructions into code for domain-specific languages (DSLs). By using grammar prompting and few-shot learning, the tool enhances the ability of LLMs to generate reliable DSL code, thereby improving development efficiency and understanding of less-known DSLs.

Title: Exploring ChatGPT’s impact on post-secondary education: A qualitative study
Description: The paper conducts a qualitative study to explore the perceptions of students and faculty regarding the use of ChatGPT in post-secondary education, focusing on its incorporation and the responses of instructors. It highlights issues such as plagiarism and assessment methods, and suggests the need for guidelines and reporting practices, contributing to the understanding of ChatGPT's role and challenges in higher education.

Title: Google Colab for Teaching CS and ML
Description: The paper discusses the use of Google Colab as a tool for teaching computer science and machine learning, highlighting its ability to provide equitable access to computational resources and AI/ML instruction. It also introduces new features such as Google Classroom integration and AI coding capabilities using Google's Gemini model, aiming to enhance the educational experience and gather feedback on these innovations.

Title: May We Consult ChatGPT in Our Human-Computer Interaction Written Exam? An Experience Report After a Professor Answered Yes
Description: The paper explores the implications of allowing students to use ChatGPT during a Human-Computer Interaction written exam, analyzing how the AI can assist with certain types of questions while still maintaining the integrity of assessing higher-level learning outcomes. It uses Bloom's taxonomy to evaluate the effectiveness of ChatGPT in solving exam questions and discusses the need for questions that require mediation and deeper understanding, contributing to the discourse on adapting educational assessment practices in the context of generative AI.

Title: Scaling Up Mastery Learning with Generative AI: Exploring How Generative AI Can Assist in the Generation and Evaluation of Mastery Quiz Questions
Description: The paper explores the use of generative AI, specifically large language models, to automate the generation and evaluation of quiz questions for mastery learning, a pedagogical approach that requires students to achieve proficiency before advancing. It introduces a framework for assessing AI-generated content against teacher-designed rubrics, aiming to enhance the scalability and effectiveness of mastery-based instruction.

Title: From "Ban It Till We Understand It" to "Resistance is Futile": How University Programming Instructors Plan to Adapt as More Students Use AI Code Generation and Explanation Tools such as ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot
Description: The paper investigates how university programming instructors plan to adapt their teaching strategies in response to the increasing use of AI code generation and explanation tools like ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot by students. Through interviews with instructors from various countries, the study captures diverse perspectives and proposes open research questions on integrating AI tools into computing education, highlighting the lack of consensus on best practices.

Title: Analyzing Developer Use of ChatGPT Generated Code in Open Source GitHub Projects
Description: The paper conducts an empirical study on the integration of ChatGPT-generated code snippets in open-source GitHub projects, revealing that a significant portion of these snippets remain unchanged after being added. The study provides insights into the use of AI-generated code in software development, emphasizing the need for careful review and modification before integration to enhance AI-assisted programming tools.

Title: Artificial Intelligence Policy: What Computing Educators and Students Should Know
Description: The paper discusses the importance of integrating AI policy education into computing curricula, highlighting recent global AI policy developments and their implications for educators and students. It emphasizes the need for future professionals to understand policy, ethics, and justice in AI to foster public trust and balance innovation with safety.

Title: Investigating the Utility of ChatGPT in the Issue Tracking System: An Exploratory Study
Description: This paper explores the use of ChatGPT in issue tracking systems, focusing on how developers interact with the AI tool to resolve software issues. The study finds that while developers frequently use ChatGPT for brainstorming, they often prefer writing their code due to concerns about the reliability of AI-generated code, as evidenced by the use of the NiCad clone detection tool to assess code integration.

Title: Iterative Student Program Planning using Transformer-Driven Feedback
Description: The paper explores the use of large language models (LLMs) to provide iterative feedback on student programming plans by generating code and evaluating it against expert-defined test suites. It demonstrates the potential of LLMs to assist in educational settings, while also identifying challenges and limitations in their application, particularly in large-scale courses.

Title: Curriculum Learning: Theories, Approaches, Applications, Tools, and Future Directions in the Era of Large Language Models
Description: The paper provides a comprehensive tutorial on curriculum learning, a paradigm in machine learning that mimics human learning by progressing from easy to hard data, highlighting its theories, approaches, applications, tools, and future directions, particularly in the context of large language models. It aims to introduce and advocate for curriculum learning's potential to enhance model generalization and convergence across various domains, addressing a gap in existing educational resources.

Title: Generative AI-Powered Educational Alignment: A Framework for Matching Syllabus Course Topics with Web Description
Description: The paper presents a framework that leverages generative AI to align online course descriptions with actual course syllabi, using models like BERT and GPT-2 to identify and rectify mismatches. This approach aims to enhance course preparation, improve student satisfaction, and support curriculum development in higher education by ensuring consistency between course offerings and descriptions.

Title: Creating Thorough Tests for AI-Generated Code is Hard
Description: The paper investigates the challenges of creating thorough test suites for code generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) and evaluates 27 test suites from the EvalPlus dataset to highlight these difficulties. It identifies deficiencies in existing test suites and proposes strategies to enhance students' abilities to develop more effective test suites for detecting subtle bugs in LLM-generated code.

Title: Leveraging Large Language Models for Preliminary Security Risk Analysis: A Mission-Critical Case Study
Description: The paper explores the use of fine-tuned large language models (LLMs) to assist in preliminary security risk analysis (PSRA) for mission-critical scenarios. It demonstrates that LLMs can reduce errors, speed up risk detection, and minimize false positives and negatives compared to human experts, leading to cost savings and allowing experts to focus on more detailed analyses.

Title: The Innovative Development of Artificial Intelligence and STEM Education-Cognition and Practice
Description: The paper explores the integration of artificial intelligence into STEM education, emphasizing the creation of new learning scenarios and applications such as immersive teaching and personalized services. It highlights the role of AI in enhancing educational processes and the importance of teachers in leveraging AI to foster innovative talent development through human-machine collaboration.

Title: LessonPlanner: Assisting Novice Teachers to Prepare Pedagogy-Driven Lesson Plans with Large Language Models
Description: The paper introduces LessonPlanner, a tool that assists novice teachers in creating pedagogy-driven lesson plans using large language models (LLMs). Through a formative study and a within-subjects study, the authors demonstrate that LessonPlanner improves the quality of lesson plans and reduces preparation workload compared to a baseline interface, while expert interviews highlight its effectiveness in suggesting teaching strategies and resources.

Title: Fairness of Large Language Models in Education
Description: The paper examines the fairness of Large Language Models in educational contexts, identifying potential biases and proposing strategies to enhance fairness through pre-processing, in-processing, and post-processing techniques. It contributes by advocating for a multidimensional approach to ensure inclusivity and fairness while leveraging AI's transformative potential in education.

Title: AI for Education (AI4EDU): Advancing Personalized Education with LLM and Adaptive Learning
Description: The paper discusses the application of large language models (LLMs) and adaptive learning in personalized education, highlighting their role as mediators in human-in-the-loop education systems to enhance personalization, flexibility, and collaboration. It identifies the potential benefits and challenges of integrating these AI technologies in educational settings, aiming to foster discussion among researchers and practitioners on advancing personalized education through AI.

Title: Assessing the Impact of Large Language Models on Cybersecurity Education: A Study of ChatGPT's Influence on Student Performance
Description: This paper empirically assesses the impact of ChatGPT on cybersecurity students' academic performance by comparing three groups with varying levels of access to the tool over three years. The study finds that while students perform similarly on weekly assignments regardless of ChatGPT access, their performance on final exams declines, highlighting potential over-reliance on AI tools for learning.

Title: Scaling Generated Feedback for Novice Teachers by Sustaining Teacher Educators' Expertise: A Design to Train LLMs with Teacher Educator Endorsement of Generated Feedback
Description: The paper presents a design for training large language models (LLMs) to generate educationally purposeful feedback for novice teachers by incorporating endorsements from experienced mathematics teacher educators. It details the infrastructure and user interface design within the Teacher Moments platform to scale and sustain expert feedback, enhancing the learning experience for novice teachers in ambitious and equitable mathematics teaching practices.

Title: Enabling access to large-language models (LLMs) at scale for higher education
Description: The paper introduces the Tufts Technology Services (TTS) LLM-Hub, a platform that simplifies access to large-language models (LLMs) for users of varying skill levels in higher education by providing Jupyter notebooks through Tufts Open OnDemand. This platform reduces technical barriers, facilitating the use of LLMs in educational and research settings, thereby enhancing data science and engineering instruction and research computing capabilities.

Title: Sustainability analysis of AI-based tools in higher education
Description: The paper introduces the SusAF framework for analyzing the sustainability of AI-based tools in higher education, aiming to provide a holistic view of sustainability by incorporating it into design and development processes, thereby enhancing the longevity and impact of digital tools in educational settings.

Title: Development of chatbots connected to Learning Management Systems for the support and formative assessment of students
Description: The paper presents the development of chatbots integrated with Learning Management Systems to provide personalized support and formative assessment for students in higher education. By leveraging Large Language Models and course-specific content, the system offers tailored responses to student inquiries, enhancing the learning experience through updated and contextually relevant information.

Title: A Piece of Theatre: Investigating How Teachers Design LLM Chatbots to Assist Adolescent Cyberbullying Education
Description: The paper presents a no-code chatbot design tool for K-12 teachers, leveraging large language models and prompt chaining to facilitate the creation of customized dialogue flows for cyberbullying education. The study explores teachers' unique requirements in designing chatbots and highlights how such tools can empower educators to simulate cyberbullying scenarios, allowing students to practice appropriate responses in a controlled environment.

Title: Advancements and Challenges of Generative AI in Higher Educational Content Creation A Technical Perspective
Description: The paper investigates the integration of Generative AI in higher education content creation, analyzing its impacts on efficiency, productivity, quality, and adaptability through literature review and case studies. It provides insights into practical applications of AI tools, ethical considerations, and the evolving role of educators, aiming to guide stakeholders in leveraging AI for personalized learning and improved educational experiences.

Title: Opportunities and Challenges in the Cultivation of Software Development Professionals in the Context of Large Language Models
Description: The paper analyzes the impact of Large Language Models (LLMs) on the cultivation of software development professionals, identifying both opportunities and challenges such as enhanced programming efficiency and the risk of over-reliance on tools. It proposes strategies for adapting professional education to these technological changes, aiming to better prepare future software developers.

Title: Enhancing classroom teaching with LLMs and RAG
Description: The paper explores the use of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines, leveraging course materials as data sources, to assist K–12 students in obtaining up-to-date information. It evaluates the effectiveness of Reddit as a data source for cybersecurity information, finding it inadequate, and demonstrates a methodology for assessing data sources' suitability for educational purposes.

Title: Equity and Fairness Challenges in Online Learning in the Age of ChatGPT
Description: The paper explores the equity and fairness challenges in online learning environments enhanced by large language models like ChatGPT, identifying a novel concern termed "Ignorant Bias," where these models may provide misleading tutoring in the absence of human instructors, potentially harming learners. The main contribution is highlighting this specific form of inequity and illustrating it with an example, emphasizing the need for addressing such biases in online education.

Title: Is ChatGPT the Academic Catalyst We've all been Waiting For?
Description: The paper investigates the impact of ChatGPT on STEM education by conducting a controlled experiment with math and computer science students, revealing that while ChatGPT can assist in problem-solving, it may lead to inaccuracies and less optimal solutions. The study highlights the benefits and challenges of integrating AI tools in educational settings, providing insights for educators and students to better adapt to AI advancements.

Title: Emerging Approaches in CG Education Aimed at Enhancing Visual Communication Skills through Reverse Engineering
Description: The paper introduces a novel educational approach in computer graphics production by employing reverse engineering techniques to enhance visual communication skills. It develops tools like the "Philosophical Observation Decomposition Table" and "Concept Decomposition Table" to analyze the interplay between language and visuals, and suggests integrating AI technologies to broaden CG education to include soft skills such as communication and creativity.

Title: JavaBench: A Benchmark of Object-Oriented Code Generation for Evaluating Large Language Models
Description: The paper introduces JavaBench, a benchmark specifically designed to evaluate large language models' (LLMs) capabilities in generating Java code, focusing on advanced object-oriented programming features. It addresses the imbalance in existing benchmarks by providing a project-level Java benchmark and demonstrates that LLMs currently lag behind undergraduate students in Java code generation, offering a new resource for assessing and improving LLM performance in this area.

Title: Exploring the Role of ChatGPT in Higher Education Institutions: Where does Latin America Stand?
Description: The paper investigates the adoption and application of ChatGPT in higher education institutions in Ecuador, Chile, and Costa Rica, highlighting the varied levels of engagement among academic and administrative staff. It contributes by providing insights into the challenges and potential of integrating ChatGPT in Latin American universities, emphasizing the need for strategic planning and training to address issues like content discernment and student inequalities.

Title: Students' Perceptions and Intentions Regarding ChatGPT Usage in Higher Education
Description: This paper investigates undergraduate students' perceptions and intentions regarding the use of ChatGPT in higher education, revealing a moderate perception but high intention to use the technology. The study identifies a positive correlation between students' perceptions and intentions, contributing to understanding the implications of ChatGPT usage in educational settings.

Title: Understanding the Adoption of ChatGPT in Higher Education: A Comparative Study with Insights from STEM and Business Students
Description: The paper investigates the adoption of ChatGPT in higher education by examining the attitudes and experiences of STEM and business students towards generative AI technologies. It employs a mixed methods approach to identify factors influencing AI adoption, providing insights that can guide the integration of AI tools in educational settings to cater to diverse academic needs.

Title: Teachers, Parents, and Students' perspectives on Integrating Generative AI into Elementary Literacy Education
Description: The paper explores the perspectives of teachers, parents, and students on the integration of generative AI systems into elementary literacy education, identifying both potential benefits and concerns. It contributes by proposing design strategies to address issues such as authorship, student agency, and bias, suggesting solutions like adult oversight and AI-role balancing to enhance educational outcomes.

Title: SelfGauge: An Intelligent Tool to Support Student Self-assessment in GenAI-enhanced Project-based Learning
Description: The paper introduces SelfGauge, an intelligent tool designed to facilitate student self-assessment in project-based learning environments enhanced by generative AI. The tool aids students in defining assessment criteria, obtaining feedback, and reflecting on their performance, thereby promoting continuous self-improvement in the context of GenAI usage and project artifact creation.

Title: GPTeach: Interactive TA Training with GPT-based Students
Description: The paper introduces GPTeach, an interactive tool for training novice teachers using GPT-based simulated students, allowing them to practice teaching without impacting real students. The study demonstrates that GPTeach enhances teaching practice by providing a flexible and engaging environment, and it offers insights and design ideas for future teacher training systems.

Title: 3rd Workshop on Human-Interactive Robot Learning (HIRL)
Description: The paper discusses the third workshop on Human-Interactive Robot Learning (HIRL), focusing on consolidating the community around teachable robots that learn interactively from humans. It highlights the impact of Large Language Models on robot teaching and explores the challenges and opportunities of robots as embodied agents.

Title: Phrasebooks Can Teach Us ChatGPT: Decoding Prompt Crafting as Function Allocation
Description: The paper introduces the concept of 'Prompting Phrasebooks' as a structured method to improve interactions with AI systems like ChatGPT, advocating for a shift from command-based to language-centric prompt engineering. It presents 'Prompt Pattern Languages' as a practical framework for users to engage effectively with AI, demonstrated through an application in AI-assisted email composition, thereby offering a new direction for teaching and mastering prompt crafting.

Title: Automated Generation of Code Contracts: Generative AI to the Rescue?
Description: The paper explores the use of Generative AI, specifically fine-tuned Large Language Models like CodeT5 and CodeT5+, to automatically generate code contracts in the form of pre- and postconditions for Java projects. It demonstrates that over 95% of the generated contracts are syntactically correct and semantically valid, potentially facilitating broader adoption of Design by Contract in software development.

Title: Custom Developer GPT for Ethical AI Solutions
Description: The paper introduces a custom Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) designed to assist developers in addressing ethical issues in AI engineering by providing guidance on legal compliance and presenting diverse ethical perspectives. The main contribution is the development of a conversational agent that helps practitioners create AI solutions that adhere to legal standards and incorporate varied moral viewpoints.

Title: ChatGPT intervenes in the application analysis of higher education classrooms
Description: The paper examines the impact of ChatGPT on higher education classrooms, highlighting both its potential benefits in enhancing intelligent teaching and self-directed learning, and its drawbacks such as impairing independent thinking and teacher-student relationships. It proposes strategies for integrating ChatGPT effectively by adapting teaching concepts, fostering critical awareness, and enforcing school regulations.

Title: GenAI in the Context of African Universities: A Crisis of Tertiary Education or Its New Dawn?
Description: This paper explores the implications of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) in African universities, identifying both opportunities and threats to tertiary education. It emphasizes the need for responsible integration of GenAI, proposing guidelines to balance technological advancements with traditional teaching methods, and highlights the potential for GenAI to enhance educational efficiency and accessibility while addressing ethical and infrastructural challenges.

Title: Analyzing Students Collaborative Problem-Solving Behaviors in Synergistic STEM+C Learning
Description: The paper introduces a methodology to analyze students' collaborative problem-solving behaviors in computational modeling tasks by expanding the Self-Regulated Learning framework and employing a Markov Chain modeling approach. It identifies distinct behavioral differences between high- and low-performing students, suggesting the potential for adaptive scaffolding to improve collaborative problem-solving in educational settings.

Title: Is GitHub copilot a substitute for human pair-programming? an empirical study
Description: The paper conducts an empirical study comparing the effectiveness of GitHub Copilot with human pair-programming in terms of code productivity and quality. It finds that while Copilot enhances productivity by increasing lines of code added, it results in lower code quality, as indicated by a higher number of lines of code being removed in subsequent stages.

Title: App Planner: Utilizing Generative AI in K-12 Mobile App Development Education
Description: The paper introduces App Planner, an interactive tool leveraging generative AI to support K-12 students in mobile app development by facilitating problem articulation and idea generation through a chat-based interface. The main contribution is demonstrating the tool's effectiveness in enhancing students' creative thinking and awareness of the human impact of their app designs, as evidenced by positive feedback from usability tests with high-school students.

Title: The Future of Learning: Large Language Models through the Lens of Students
Description: The paper investigates the interactions of students with ChatGPT, a large language model, highlighting their mixed emotions and ethical concerns about its use in education. It emphasizes the need for cautious application of such AI technologies in learning environments due to their human-like qualities and potential adverse consequences.

Title: Instructional Approaches Complementing the Use of Generative Artificial Intelligence in Higher Education
Description: This paper investigates instructional strategies in higher education to effectively integrate generative AI into the learning process, proposing a combination of peer-supported incremental learning, a master/apprentice model, and a growth mindset to guide students' use of AI while preserving academic integrity.

Title: The Promise and Peril of ChatGPT in Higher Education: Opportunities, Challenges, and Design Implications
Description: The paper investigates the use of ChatGPT in higher education by conducting focus groups and participatory design sessions with students and stakeholders, identifying opportunities and challenges, and providing insights into how ChatGPT can be effectively integrated into educational settings.

Title: Exploration and research of generative artificial intelligence on higher vocational education
Description: The paper investigates the impact of generative artificial intelligence on higher vocational education, focusing on its effects on students' learning experiences and teachers' roles. It proposes a shift towards a collaborative "teacher-machine-student" learning model to enhance educational outcomes and addresses the associated risks and challenges.

Title: IT Higher Education Teachers and Trust in AI-Enabled Ed-Tech: Implications for Adoption of AI in Higher Education
Description: The paper investigates the factors influencing cognitive trust among IT higher education instructors in AI-enabled educational technology, highlighting how trust issues affect the adoption of AI in higher education. The study provides insights into the barriers to AI integration in academia and suggests that addressing transparency, reliability, and ethical concerns is crucial for broader acceptance and implementation.

Title: Investigating the Impact of Generative AI on Students and Educators: Evidence and Insights from the Literature
Description: The paper investigates the impact of generative AI on students and educators in higher education by conducting a scientometric and text analysis of existing literature, revealing distinct usage patterns and shared concerns such as equity, rule clarity, and job displacement.

Title: Opportunities and Challenges of Generative Artificial Intelligence in Facilitating Learning for Chinese University Students
Description: The paper investigates the perspectives of Chinese university students on the use of generative artificial intelligence technologies, such as ChatGPT, in their learning processes. It identifies the opportunities and challenges these technologies present, emphasizing the need for universities to adapt assignments and assessments to effectively integrate AI into education, thereby enhancing personalized learning and preparing students for an AI-driven future.

Title: The Potential and Implications of Generative AI on HCI Education
Description: The paper explores the integration of generative AI into a 10-week undergraduate HCI module, highlighting its potential as a pedagogical tool. It provides insights into how AI can be used to develop project ideas, create design resources, and reflect students' understanding, while also discussing potential pitfalls and the importance of assessing students' AI literacy.

Title: Educator and Student Perspectives on the Impact of Generative AI on Assessments in Higher Education
Description: The paper investigates the impact of generative AI on assessment practices in higher education by surveying educators and students to understand their perspectives. It highlights the need for assessment reform that incorporates AI usage, emphasizes critical thinking, and addresses concerns about academic integrity and creativity.

Title: Do Human Beliefs and Traits Influence the Adoption of ChatGPT among Programming Students?
Description: The paper investigates the influence of human beliefs and traits on the adoption of ChatGPT among programming students, using the Theory of Reasoned Action. It identifies that academic stress and computer self-efficacy positively affect attitudes towards AI use in programming, while risk propensity, neuroticism, and social norms do not significantly impact attitudes or behavioral intentions, providing insights for both industry and academia.

Title: What Teaching Databases Taught Us about Researching Databases: Extended Talk Abstract
Description: The paper discusses the development of educational systems at Duke University designed to aid students in learning and debugging database queries, which have enhanced teaching scalability and inspired new research directions in database systems. It also highlights the emerging need for skills in evaluating AI-generated queries due to the rise of generative AI, proposing future research directions to address this challenge.

Title: Toward Effective AI Support for Developers: A survey of desires and concerns
Description: The paper surveys the desires and concerns of software developers regarding the integration of AI tools into their workflows, highlighting the transformative potential of AI in enhancing productivity and creativity while addressing issues of transparency, education, and ethics.

Title: Large Language Models in Computer Science Education: A Systematic Literature Review
Description: This paper conducts a systematic literature review to evaluate the impact of large language models (LLMs) on computer science and engineering education, focusing on their effectiveness in improving learning experiences, supporting personalized education, and assisting educators in curriculum development. The study addresses key research questions to provide insights into the educational benefits, challenges, and future research directions related to the use of LLMs in educational settings.

Title: A Systematic Literature Mapping of Early Generative AI Research is CS Education
Description: The paper systematically maps 82 early publications on the impact of generative AI tools in computer science education, categorizing them by population, AI usage, and evaluation methods, providing a foundational literature map and a roadmap for future research in this emerging field.

Title: What Can Computer Science Educators Learn From the Failures of Top-Down Pedagogy?
Description: The paper examines the limitations of top-down pedagogy in computer science education, drawing parallels with historical educational debates in literacy and mathematics. It argues against the exclusive use of generative AI tools without foundational teaching, advocating for a balanced approach that considers cognitive, motivational, and social factors in pedagogy.

Title: Prompt-Engineering Strategies for Minimizing Bias in Large Language Model Outputs: Applications in Computing Education
Description: The paper explores prompt-engineering strategies to reduce bias in outputs from large language models, specifically within the context of computer science education. It provides empirical insights and practical strategies for educators to create fairness-aware educational content, contributing to the curriculum of Ethics in AI.

Title: Building AI-Powered Responsible Workforce by Integrating Large Language Models into Computer Science Curriculum
Description: The paper discusses an NSF-sponsored project aimed at integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) into the computer science curriculum to enhance students' programming, software development, and problem-solving skills while educating them on ethical AI practices. The project seeks to renovate the entire department-level curriculum, rather than individual courses, to prepare a new generation of AI-powered responsible developers.

Title: Exploring the Adoption of Generative AI Tools in Computer Science Education: A Student Survey
Description: This paper investigates the adoption and use of generative AI tools by computer science students at the University of Applied Sciences Campus Vienna, revealing high acceptance and frequent use for academic tasks. It highlights the need for institutional guidelines and ethical considerations, contributing insights for educators and policymakers on integrating AI technologies responsibly in education.

Title: From Automation to Cognition: Redefining the Roles of Educators and Generative AI in Computing Education
Description: The paper explores the integration of Generative AI in computing education, proposing curriculum and assessment changes to enhance learning. It suggests redesigning assignments to focus on students' use of GenAI and emphasizes the role of educators in fostering critical thinking and self-evaluation, advocating for further research on the impact of GenAI in educational settings.

Title: Designing LLM-Resistant Programming Assignments: Insights and Strategies for CS Educators
Description: The paper investigates the effectiveness of Large Language Models (LLMs) in solving programming assignments and identifies their limitations, particularly in context-specific and visually-oriented tasks. It proposes strategies for educators to design assignments that resist LLM-generated solutions, ensuring authentic student engagement and learning.

Title: On Automated Essay Grading using Large Language Models
Description: The paper investigates the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) such as GPT-4, GPT-3.5, PaLM, and LLaMA2 for Automated Essay Grading (AEG), demonstrating that these models can achieve substantial agreement with human markers in essay scoring and provide qualitative feedback closely aligned with human assessments, thus highlighting their potential to improve educational assessment practices.

Title: Does Multiple Choice Have a Future in the Age of Generative AI? A Posttest-only RCT
Description: The paper investigates the effectiveness of multiple-choice questions (MCQs) compared to open-response questions in learning, using a posttest-only randomized control trial with tutors. It finds that MCQs are as effective as open-response tasks but more time-efficient, and demonstrates the potential of GPT models for autograding open responses, contributing a dataset to support transparency and reproducibility in educational assessments.

Title: Beyond the Hype: A Comprehensive Review of Current Trends in Generative AI Research, Teaching Practices, and Tools
Description: This paper conducts a comprehensive review of current trends in generative AI within computing education, highlighting its impact on teaching practices and tool development. It synthesizes findings from literature, surveys, and interviews to provide insights into how GenAI is being integrated into classrooms, offering personalized feedback and teaching both programming and prompting skills, thereby expanding the understanding of GenAI's role and perceptions in educational settings.

Title: AI Integration in the IT Professional Workplace: A Scoping Review and Interview Study with Implications for Education and Professional Competencies
Description: The paper conducts a scoping review and interview study to explore the impact of AI technologies, such as generative AI and large language models, on IT professionals and computing curricula. It highlights the need for updated competency frameworks and educational curricula to prepare professionals for AI-driven workplaces, emphasizing the importance of understanding AI's role in task augmentation, privacy, security, and ethical challenges.

Title: Sociotechnical AI Education Course Design for CS Majors and Non-Majors
Description: The paper presents a socio-technical curriculum for an introductory AI course designed to be accessible to both CS majors and non-majors, aiming to democratize AI education and enhance inclusivity. It provides a detailed course structure with weekly activities that foster a multidisciplinary perspective, thereby equipping students with the necessary skills to engage with the ethical implications of AI technology.

Title: Artificial Intimacy: Exploring Normativity and Personalization Through Fine-tuning LLM Chatbots
Description: The paper explores the personalization of chatbots by fine-tuning Large Language Models (LLMs) on individual social media data to create more intimate and normative interactions. It highlights the ethical implications of such personalization, particularly the emotional manipulation and expectations of reciprocity that arise from the mimicry of emotional connections in fine-tuned chatbots.

Title: Automatic Short Answer Grading in the LLM Era: Does GPT-4 with Prompt Engineering beat Traditional Models?
Description: The paper conducts a comparative analysis of traditional machine learning models and GPT-4, enhanced with prompt engineering, for Automatic Short Answer Grading (ASAG). It finds that while traditional models generally outperform LLMs, GPT-4 shows potential when optimized with specific prompt strategies, contributing insights into developing more efficient multilingual ASAG systems.

Title: Nurturing Code Quality: Leveraging Static Analysis and Large Language Models for Software Quality in Education
Description: The paper investigates the integration of static analysis tools and Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT in educational settings to enhance software quality. It presents an experiment with 155 student submissions, revealing insights into the effectiveness of LLMs in code review and their impact on learning outcomes, ultimately advocating for the inclusion of code review practices in computing curricula to improve software quality awareness.

Title: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility: The Role of Software Engineers
Description: The paper outlines the evolving role of Software Engineers in the context of digital transformation and AI advancements, proposing 10 research challenges to prepare future engineers for technical, social, and ethical complexities. It emphasizes the need for redefining roles, integrating AI, transforming education, evolving standards, and assessing impacts to ensure responsible and skilled handling of the profession's evolving demands.

Title: TutorCraftEase: Enhancing Pedagogical Question Creation with Large Language Models
Description: The paper introduces TutorCraftEase, an interactive system utilizing large language models to assist teachers in generating pedagogical questions. The system allows for rapid question creation at various difficulty levels, significantly reducing teachers' workload and time while maintaining question quality comparable to those crafted by experienced educators.

Title: From Passive Watching to Active Learning: Empowering Proactive Participation in Digital Classrooms with AI Video Assistant
Description: The paper introduces SAM, an AI-powered educational platform that integrates video content with a context-aware chat interface to facilitate active learning in digital classrooms. Through studies involving university students and crowdsourced participants, SAM demonstrated improved learning outcomes and high user satisfaction, highlighting its potential to enhance online education by encouraging proactive student engagement.

Title: From Code to Concepts: Textbook-Driven Knowledge Tracing with LLMs in CS1
Description: The paper introduces a framework that utilizes Large Language Models (LLMs) to perform Knowledge Tracing in CS1 courses by analyzing student homework code submissions. This approach allows for dynamic updates of a student's knowledge state, enabling the provision of targeted feedback and personalized study materials, thereby enhancing the learning process.

Title: Feedback on Feedback: Student’s Perceptions for Feedback from Teachers and Few-Shot LLMs
Description: The paper investigates the use of large language models (LLMs) for generating feedback for students in higher education and examines students' perceptions of such feedback. It finds that students generally cannot distinguish between LLM-generated and teacher-generated feedback, although they may resist auto-generated feedback when aware of its source, highlighting the importance of integrating teachers in the feedback process.

Title: How Do Hackathons Foster Creativity? Towards Automated Evaluation of Creativity at Scale
Description: The paper conducted a computational analysis of 193,353 hackathon projects to study how hackathon formats foster creativity, refining the dataset to 10,363 projects based on usefulness and novelty. It identified strategies for organizers to enhance creativity in hackathons and explored the use of large language models to augment the evaluation of creative outcomes, offering insights for broader creativity research.

Title: Classroom Simulacra: Building Contextual Student Generative Agents in Online Education for Learning Behavioral Simulation
Description: The paper introduces a novel approach to simulate student learning behaviors in online education by developing a transferable iterative reflection (TIR) module that enhances large language models. This method improves the accuracy of student simulations by capturing detailed learning dynamics and inter-student correlations, utilizing data collected from a custom-built online education system.

Title: AutoPBL: An LLM-powered Platform to Guide and Support Individual Learners Through Self Project-based Learning
Description: The paper introduces AutoPBL, a platform that integrates large language models (LLMs) to guide and support learners in self project-based learning (SPBL). Through a user study, the platform demonstrated improved learning outcomes and behaviors by providing structured guidance and timely assistance, enhancing the SPBL experience.

Title: Generative AI in Education: Developing Personalized Learning Experiences with Hyperspherical Variational Self-Attention Autoencoder
Description: The paper introduces the Hyperspherical Variational Self-Attention Autoencoder (HVSAE), a novel deep generative model that combines Variational Autoencoders and self-attention mechanisms to generate personalized educational content. This approach aims to alleviate teachers' workload and enhance students' learning outcomes by tailoring educational resources to individual learning situations.

Title: Exploring the Design Space of Cognitive Engagement Techniques with AI-Generated Code for Enhanced Learning
Description: The paper explores cognitive engagement techniques to enhance learning for novice programmers using AI-generated code, identifying and refining methods that promote deeper engagement and improve skill development. The main contribution is the identification of an effective technique that involves guiding learners through a step-by-step problem-solving process with interactive AI dialog, improving their ability to apply programming concepts independently.

Title: Traversing New Horizons: An Exploration of Educational Policies on Generative AI
Description: The paper explores how tertiary academic institutions are integrating generative AI into their course policies by analyzing over 100 university policies and syllabi using NLP and unsupervised clustering techniques. Its main contribution is providing insights into the patterns and best practices of AI policy discussions across different institutions, highlighting the ethical considerations and challenges in educational settings.

Title: The Role of Generative AI in Higher Education: A Decade of Current Status and Future Prospects
Description: This paper conducts a comprehensive bibliometric and scientometric analysis of the application of Generative AI in higher education over the past decade, highlighting its impact on personalized learning, teaching assessment, and interdisciplinary education. It identifies trends and challenges, such as academic integrity and educational equity, providing insights for future research and discussions in the field.

Title: Research on Steganography Course with Large Language Model ChatGPT Assisted Learning
Description: The paper explores the integration of large language models, specifically ChatGPT, into a Steganography course to enhance teaching and learning outcomes. It demonstrates that using ChatGPT can improve students' understanding and skills in Steganography by fostering active observation, independent research, and critical thinking, aligning with industry requirements.

Title: Configuring and Monitoring Students' Interactions with Generative AI Tools: Supporting Teacher Autonomy
Description: The paper presents a system designed to enhance teacher autonomy by allowing educators to monitor and control students' interactions with Generative AI tools, aligning AI outputs with educational objectives. The system was evaluated with secondary-school teachers, demonstrating its usefulness in monitoring student behavior and increasing teacher control over AI-generated content, while also gathering feedback for further development.

Title: PAIGE: Examining Learning Outcomes and Experiences with Personalized AI-Generated Educational Podcasts
Description: The paper investigates the effectiveness of AI-generated podcasts as an educational tool by converting textbook chapters into personalized audio content tailored to individual learner profiles. It demonstrates that personalized AI-generated podcasts enhance learning outcomes and engagement compared to traditional textbook reading, offering insights and design recommendations for integrating AI in educational settings.

Title: Co-designing Large Language Model Tools for Project-Based Learning with K12 Educators
Description: The paper explores the co-design process with K-12 educators to integrate large language models into project-based learning, addressing challenges in project design, management, and assessment.
